history.content:
Don't know about taking CS189 after Stat154, but I can add about taking CS 281A as an undergrad.

I was able to take CS281A last fall as an undergrad, the professors prioritized grad students first but once the waitlist was cleared out, I talked to the prof and he added me. Just need to be persistent and keep attending class and keep up with the homework. You need a strong math background though (helpful "prerequisite" courses would be mathy classes EE 126, EE 127, CS 188, CS 189, CS 182, Math 104, Math 110. I had taken all of them). 

That being said, I felt like the course was somewhat redundant after taking CS 188 and CS 189. They give a high-level overview of many topics that you've already seen in 188 and 189, albeit that they do take a slightly more rigorous approach. A rough topics list is as follows (*Starred topics are those that are new/not seen before in cs188/cs189) 

Math Review: Random Variables, CLT, Multivariate Derivatives, PSD Matrices

Likelihood Ratio Test, Confusion Matrix, ROC Curves, Neyman-Pearson Theorem

*Algorithmic Fairness: Equal Positive Rate, Equal Error Rate, Calibration by Group

*Strategic Adaptation, Feedback Effect of Rational Agents

Empirical Risk Minimization, Perceptron Algorithm, *Mistake Bound, “Leave-one-out” error

Features: Kernels (Polynomial, RBF, nonlinear lifts), Neural Networks, Random Features

Optimization: Gradient Descent, Lipschitz and Strong-convexity, convergence.

Learning Rate Decay, Mini-batching, Adam. Backpropagation

*Generalization, Average Stability, Uniform Stability, Uniform Convergence

*Function Classes, VC Dimension, Differential Privacy

Classical Bias-Variance Tradeoff vs Overparameterized Regime (Modern Empirical Reality)

Benchmarking and Overfitting, hold-out method

*Adaptive Classifiers, Leaderboard Error

ML History, Datasets

Causal Graph Model (Bayesian Network): Confounders, Colliders, Mediators

*Do-Intervention, Adjustment Estimator, Propensity Scores

*Causality, Simpson’s and Lord’s Paradox, Causal Inference, Quasi-Experiments

Sequential Decisions, PID Feedback Control

Dynamic Programming, Bellman Optimality, Q-functions, Policies, LQR, MDP

Regret, Bandit Problems, Exploration and Exploitation, Reinforcement Learning

children.subject: Also if you're majoring in only CS or EECS, you should have no problem taking cs 189 for degree requirement purposes after takins stat 154
Thanks so much! It really helps me a lot and gives me some ideas on what I should do next! Thanks again and good luck!

history.content: I am wondering after taking STAT154 (Machine Learning), can CS189 still be used to satisfied the requirement for CS major? Furthermore, is it possible to take CS281A (statistical learning theory) as an undergraduate senior student? Thanks!
history.subject: ML after STAT154
